channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Greece Replaces Finance Minister in Cabinet Shuffle
item.description: The new finance minister, Gikas Hardouvelis, a professor and former government adviser, will try to enact a tough economic reform program imposed by Greece’s international creditors.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Yang Yong on Documenting the Damage to China’s Rivers
item.description: A geologist who is documenting the degradation of China’s waterways discusses what he has learned and how rapid development affects people living along these waterways.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Plans to build a dam that would submerge this area around the Jinsha River on the border of Sichuan and Yunnan Provinces have led to a scramble for mineral extraction. Slag and wastewater from more than 100 mines have flowed into the river.

item.title: Video of Mass Sexual Assault Taints Egypt Inauguration
item.description: A grainy video of a crowd of men assaulting a woman that circulated on the Internet presented the new Egyptian president with an immediate test on assault and harassment of women.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:description: Celebrations in Tahrir Square after the inauguration of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi on Sunday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: June 9
item.description: A man taking a bath at a railway station in Jammu, Jammu and Kashmir, as a heat wave swept across northern India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A man cooling off at a railway station in Jammu, Jammu and Kashmir, as summer temperatures soared across northern India.

item.title: Apprehension and Apathy Compete With Excitement in Brazil
item.description: A grim mood is dividing many Brazilians as resentment simmers over the ballooning costs of the World Cup and the economy lacks the desired pace.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Hundreds of fans gathered to take a look at the Arena Corinthians stadium in São Paulo on Sunday ahead of the opening of the World Cup.

item.title: Russians Yearning to Join Ukraine Battle Find Lots of Helping Hands
item.description: A few days in the border areas provided ample evidence that some Russians are answering online calls and other pleas and traveling to eastern Ukraine to join the fight.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Vostok Battalion, a pro-Russia separatist militia, displayed surface-to-air missiles and other heavy weapons last week in Donetsk, Ukraine.

item.title: Syrian Leader Declares ‘General Amnesty’ for Prisoners
item.description: Human rights advocates have been disappointed by President Bashar al-Assad’s previous amnesties, but the timing of the move offered some hope.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Moscow Court Sentences 5 to Prison for Contract Killing of Journalist
item.description: The sentences marked the toughest punishment to date in the long-running investigation into Anna Politkovskaya’s death, but it is still unclear who paid for and ordered the killing.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: Ibragim Makhmudov, Lom-Ali Gaitukayev, Rustam Makhmudov and Sergey Khadzhikurbanov waited in court on Monday before being sentenced to prison for the 2006 murder of the investigative journalist Anna Politkovskaya.

item.title: At Swearing-In, Ex-General Vows ‘Inclusive’ Egypt
item.description: Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, who led the military takeover that ousted President Mohamed Morsi, formalized his grip on power but must now overcome economic dysfunction and political polarization.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: The inauguration of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, who led Egypt after a military takeover, was celebrated in Tahrir Square.

item.title: India Ink: No Alarm Before Waters Rose, Say Survivors of Dam Flood
item.description: Four bodies were recovered Monday after 24 students and their tour guide were swept away when the floodgates opened at a dam in the state of Himachal Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA and SRIRAM KARRI
item.media:description: Rescuers searching the Beas River in the northern state of Himachal Pradesh after 24 students and their tour guide were swept away when the water level rose suddenly. As of Monday evening, four bodies had been recovered.

item.title: India Ink: An Ancient Form of Wrestling Fades in Mumbai
item.description: Practiced in India for more than 2,000 years, the traditional sport of Kushti is facing a shortage of sponsors and funding.
item.dc:creator: By UDIT THAKUR
item.media:description: In Mumbai, wrestlers practiced the traditional Indian sport of Kushti, which is a type of wrestling on earthen floors. The sport's fan base is eroding, which has fueled a push to modernize the centuries-old athletic tradition.

item.title: Apparent Anti-Semitic Pun From National Front’s Jean-Marie Le Pen Draws Criticism
item.description: Activists pledged to file a criminal complaint against Jean-Marie Le Pen of the National Front after he used an apparently anti-Semitic pun about ovens to dismiss critics.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Twin Bombing Near Kurdish Party Office in North Iraq Kills 30
item.description: A double bombing targeted the offices of a Kurdish political party in the northern Iraqi town of Tuz Khurmato, local officials and medical workers said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: Smoke rising from the site of the attack in the northern Iraqi town of Tuz Khurmato on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Disappointed Immigration Applicants Sue Canada
item.description: More than 1,400 Chinese plaintiffs have filed a lawsuit against the Canadian immigration authorities after Canada announced it was canceling its immigrant investor program along with tens of thousands of outstanding applications.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:credit: Kim Stallknecht for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vancouver has been a favorite destination of rich Chinese who immigrate to Canada.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The True Cost of China’s Fakes
item.description: The government could learn something from how online shoppers deal with the problem of counterfeit goods.
item.dc:creator: By YU HUA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Kabul’s City on the Hill
item.description: A mountain neighborhood of the Afghan capital is a microcosm of a country divided, by ethnicity and status.
item.dc:creator: By MAY JEONG

item.title: Taliban Claim Responsibility for Pakistan Airport Attack
item.description: Ten gunmen infiltrated the international airport in Karachi, where 29 people died, including all of the attackers, in an extended battle with security forces.
item.dc:creator: By ZIA ur-REHMAN and SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Gunmen waged an extended firefight with security forces at Pakistan’s largest international airport before being killed.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Accuses Vietnam of Ramming Ships to Stop Rig
item.description: China says that Vietnamese ships have rammed Chinese vessels 1,416 times since a dispute over a Chinese oil rig in the South China Sea flared up in May.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Vietnamese video showing a Chinese Coast Guard ship chasing a Vietnamese vessel near a Chinese oil rig on June 1. China says that Vietnam is the real aggressor and that Chinese vessels have been rammed 1,416 times in recent weeks.

item.title: Economic Growth in Japan Stronger Than First Thought
item.description: Tokyo said the economy grew an annualized 6.7 percent in the first quarter, beating the initial estimate of 5.9 percent.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Lens Blog: Photographing a ‘Difficult Love’ in South Africa
item.description: Zanele Muholi has been an activist using photography to champion the rights of black lesbians and transgender people in South Africa.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By ALEXIS OKEOWO
item.media:credit: Zanele Muholi/Courtesy of Stevenson, Cape Town and Johannesburg

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Communist Party Parlance, Adultery Has Many Names
item.description: China’s top antigraft body actually used the Chinese word for adultery last week while announcing the expulsion of a party member, rather than oft-used euphemisms like “moral corruption.”
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Liu Zhijun, former minister of railways, was among the fallen officials pinned with the "moral corruption" label.

item.title: Terrorists Attack Airport in Pakistan, Killing 13
item.description: Ten gunmen infiltrated Karachi international airport, engaging in an extended firefight against security forces, killing 13 people before security forces killed the militants and regained control of the airport.
item.dc:creator: By ZIA ur-REHMAN and SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Gunmen waged an extended firefight with security forces at Pakistan’s largest international airport before being killed.

item.title: Japan Seeks to Squelch Its Tiny Cars
item.description: Saying the nation’s automakers are too focused on a niche market, the government has sharply raised taxes on the tiny vehicles, prompting an outcry.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:credit: Kentaro Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Takeshi Suzuki sells coffee from his microvan in Shinshiro, Japan.

item.title: As World Cup Arrives, Some Brazilians Play an Acrobatic Variation of the Game
item.description: Futevolei is a popular Brazilian version of beach volleyball in which players use any move that would be legal in soccer to get the ball back over the net.
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.media:description: A player in Rio de Janeiro executed a “shark attack,” a spike made with the foot.

item.title: Critics of P.O.W. Swap Question the Absence of a Wider Agreement
item.description: Many in the Afghan government believed that American officials misled them into thinking that the prisoner swap would not be done unless it was connected to a broader peace effort.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: Uncredited/Voice of Jihad Website, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The exchange of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl for five Taliban leaders at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, continued to draw questions from congressional leaders on Sunday.
